ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Incorrect of cmath header in c files
ygData.msgSnippet: Well, Cantera is written in C++, and is designed for use in C++ programs or one of the supported interfaces (Python, MATLAB, Fortran) through the clib

	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Well,

Cantera is written in C++, and is designed for use in C++ programs o=
r  
one of the supported interfaces (Python, MATLAB, Fortran) through the  =

"clib" interface library (which, despite its name, should be compiled  
wi=
th a C++ compiler).  I use an Intel Mac, and compile everything  
with g++ =
with no problems.  I'm not aware of any C files that come  
with Cantera, e=
xcept some in the "ext" directory, but when I do a  
"grep" on "cmath" the =
only place it shows up is in an "include"  
statement in "ct_defs.h" which =
no external C code in the "ext"  
directory includes.  So the C code must b=
e user code... I would  
recommend that all users who write in C to take th=
e plunge and learn C 
++!

As before... the best way to write your first C+=
+ Cantera program is  
to run the script "ctnew" to create a "demo.cpp" pro=
gram, and a  
"demo.mak" makefile to build it.  If Cantera is properly inst=
alled,  
this should build without error. Then you can modify "demo.mak" as=
  
you like, even including C-like constructs, as long as they are  
accept=
able to a C++ compiler...

Dave



On Dec 6, 2007, at 7:56 AM, spdomin wrot=
e:

> Greetings,
>
> As we port Cantera to new platforms, we sometimes note=
 a few set of  
> changes that need to be made to the Cantera code reposito=
ry.
>
> The latest issue, which we are noting during our Intel Mac builds, =
 
> is Cantera=92s use of cmath in c files (noted by myCFile.c). In  
> rea=
lity, cmath should only be used in C++ files, i.e., myCppFile.C.  
> For c =
files, math.h should be used. Although the c standard is  
> expected to ad=
opt the legal use of cmath, the current c99 standard  
> does not allow thi=
s usage.
>
> Unfortunately, simply changing the name of the files from myCF=
ile.c  
> to myCFile.C results in a large amount of errors which seems to  =

> indicate use of c-code that is not compatible with the C++  
> standard.=
 I have not investigated this issue to learn more. Our  
> local approach h=
as been to change cmath to math.h.
>
> Regards,
>
> Stefan 


--Apple-Mail-4--392531185
